Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Respondent was absent from Canada for 925 days out of the required 1095 days, leaving him 560 days short of the three-year residency requirement
Remedy_Requested: Minister's appeal to set aside the Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court allowed the Minister's appeal and set aside the Citizenship Judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to meet physical presence requirement; engaged in business investments abroad
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of Re Koo test; consideration of irrelevant factors such as business investments
Assessment_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada during the four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a Citizenship Judge’s decision to the Federal Court
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least three years (1095 days) of residence in Canada within four years before application
Relief_Sought: Overturning of citizenship grant due to non-compliance with residency requirements
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have been physically present in Canada for at least 1095 days within the four years preceding the application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of compliance with residency requirement
Outcome: Minister's appeal allowed; citizenship approval set aside
Harm_Assessment: Unlawful grant of citizenship contrary to statutory requirements
Cause_Description: Respondent did not meet the statutory residency requirements but was granted citizenship
Evidence_Handling: The Citizenship Judge improperly weighed non-residency factors such as business investments
Evidence_Issues: Irrelevant consideration of business ties abroad instead of focusing on physical presence
Residency_Compliance: Not met – only 170 days of presence in the required 1095-day period
Evidence_Assessment: Absence records were central; judge erred by downplaying them
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge misapplied the Re Koo test and relied on irrelevant considerations, rendering the decision unreasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Improper reliance on extraneous factors unrelated to physical presence
